title: rash after new medicine(Drug Rash)
description: A drug rash is a skin reaction caused by a medication. It can range from mild itching to serious allergic reactions. It may appear hours, days, or even weeks after starting a new drug.

sections.heading: Common Symptoms
sections.content:
Red spots or bumps

Itchy skin

Hives (raised, itchy welts)

Peeling or blistering skin

Swelling (face, lips, or throat in serious cases)

Fever (in more severe reactions)

sections.heading: Common Causes
sections.content:
Antibiotics (e.g. penicillin, sulfa drugs)

Anticonvulsants (for seizures)

Anti-inflammatory drugs (like ibuprofen or aspirin)

Chemotherapy drugs

Allergy medications

Reaction can also occur due to interaction between two drugs.

sections.heading: Precautions
sections.content:
Always inform your doctor of any allergies or past drug reactions.

When starting a new medicine:
- Monitor for rashes, especially in the first 7–10 days.
- Start with a low dose if advised by your doctor.
- Avoid self-medicating with antibiotics or painkillers.
- Tell your doctor if you’re on multiple medications – some may interact.

sections.heading: What to Do If Rash Appears
sections.content:
Mild Rash (no fever or swelling):
- Stop the medication (only after confirming with your doctor)
- Take an antihistamine (eg, cetirizine or loratadine)
- Apply calamine lotion or mild hydrocortisone cream to reduce itch
- Drink water and avoid hot showers or skin irritants

Serious Rash or Allergic Reaction:
Call emergency services if you have:
- Swelling of face, lips, tongue
- Breathing difficulty
- High fever
- Blisters, peeling skin
- Purple/red patches
- Rash spreading rapidly

This may be a serious reaction like Stevens-Johnson Syndrome or anaphylaxis.

sections.heading: When to See a Doctor
sections.content:
Rash lasts more than 2–3 days

It’s spreading or very itchy

You have fever, fatigue, or body aches

Any swelling or breathing difficulty

You're unsure if the rash is drug-related

sections.heading: Emergency Medicines (prescribed by doctor)
sections.content:
Antihistamines – for itching/allergy relief

Steroids (oral or cream) – for inflammation

Epinephrine injection (EpiPen) – for severe allergic reactions

IV fluids, hospital care – for severe skin reactions

sections.heading: What Not to Do
sections.content:
Don’t take the drug again unless your doctor says it’s safe

Don’t ignore even a small rash if it gets worse

Don’t apply strong creams unless prescribed

Don’t take new meds without telling your doctor about the rash
